title: Endless Image Replication
text:
Endless Image Replication

Context
In this blog, I play around with OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-5 image generation capabilities. Beginning with a photo of my dog, I repeatedly give the prompt ‚Äúcreate a replica of this image. don‚Äôt change a thing‚Äù, feeding the output of each iteration as the input of the next.

I was inspired by this Reddit post, where a user shows how an image of a person became completely unrecognizable after the 74th iteration! My experiment didn‚Äôt go that far though, yielding different (and a little more underwhelming) results.



Results
I performed 11 iterations of the prompt using the GPT-5 model. Here‚Äôs an animation of my results:

The first iteration was extremely good ‚Äì the original image is on the left and the output is on the right. I initially had high hopes, since there are no noticeable differences I can spot when seeing the images side by side.










However, it went quickly downhill after that. The biggest jump seemed to be within the third and fourth images, where the fourth image suddenly gained lots of noise and a higher contrast/sharpness.










After that, it seemed to hit a plateau where the image became black and white and extremely noisy, with the outline of my dog still slightly distinguishable. This was the final photo after 11 rounds:





Reflections
I couldn‚Äôt find any detailed and definitive source online regarding how the GPT-5 model generates images, but I‚Äôm assuming what happened here is that some noise/mismatches got introduced at some stage, which then got amplified as the iterations continued. According to an article on The Verge, the GPT-4o model uses an autoregressive approach (not diffusion), where it generates an image token by token, just like text. Instead of starting with random noise, like with diffusion, it predicts a sequence of image tokens that make up the image. Because of this, I‚Äôm surprised that the model introduced so much static/noise and didn‚Äôt veer off the path like the Reddit example.
In fact, I even fed the final image into GPT-5 and asked if it could identify what it was. It said: ‚ÄúThis is an image of a dog lying in the grass. The photo appears to have been processed with a strong filter or edge-detection effect, which makes it look like a high-contrast sketch or engraving. You can still make out the dog‚Äôs head, body, and the surrounding grass and trees in the background, though the details are stylized.‚Äù Therefore, it‚Äôs puzzling as to why it didn‚Äôt retain a more obvious ‚Äúdog token‚Äù in its image generation process.
To push the model a bit further, I asked it to ‚Äúgenerate an image of what you think the original photo looked like.‚Äù This was what it generated ‚Äì pretty good!
(From left to right: the original image, the final image, and the reconstructed image)

title: Creating My Own AI Agent
text:
Creating My Own AI Agent


Context
Recently, I‚Äôve been curious about agentic AI ‚Äì especially after seeing how companies like OpenAI and Salesforce are integrating these capabilities into their products. The whole idea felt a bit overwhelming at first, but I‚Äôve learned that the best way for me to make sense of and get familiar with these technical concepts is just to dive in and play around with them.
In this blog post, I document my experience creating my own (very basic and simple) AI agent using Make, a site that allows you to visually create, build and automate workflows!



What is agentic AI?
Agentic AI is AI that is proactive ‚Äì it has agency to perform tasks by planning, acting, and sometimes proactively deciding how to reach a goal across multiple steps or tools. Generative AI, on the other hand, is more reactive ‚Äì it only responds to prompts given by the user.
Putting things together in Make
My experiment was simple and straightforward ‚Äì I wanted to pull in events from my Google Calendar, run them through AI to get notes on how I should prepare for these events, and save everything neatly into a Google Sheet.
The workflow was as follows: - Google Calendar = fetches my events - Make AI Toolkit = asks ‚Äúwhat should I do to prepare for each event?‚Äù - Google Sheets = stores the answers
Make makes this process simple and visually intuitive to understand. Each circle is a module, which can draw from a wide range of apps/formats/platforms like Google Drive, JSON, OpenAI, and so on. When you add a module, you may have to give permissions (such as permission for Make to access my Google Calendar) or enter API keys (such as if you were using the OpenAI module). Modules can then be linked together to form a flow!

While the layout was extremely intuitive, I still ran into many issues throughout this process. For example, in one of my earlier iterations, I didn‚Äôt have the Google Sheets module and was attempting to get the output directly from the Make AI Toolkit.
However, The way Make handles data means every calendar event comes in as a separate ‚Äúbundle.‚Äù This meant I wasn‚Äôt getting one nice weekly checklist; rather, I was getting ten scattered AI outputs.

So, I consulted ChatGPT for help. I fed it an image of my workflow and had it suggest solutions for me to implement. It suggested either 1) using an aggregator component after the Google Calendar to collect all event details into a single text block or 2) adding another AI component to summarize the results into one output. I wasn‚Äôt able to get these recommendations to work, so I instead suggested adding a Google Sheet and asked ChatGPT where to go from there. From there, it was able to successfully instruct me how to configure this component to add each checklist as a row in a Google Sheet that lives in my personal Google Drive!
I thought this part was pretty cool ‚Äì I was using AI to help me build an AI agent.



The AI responses
Overall, I thought the checklists that the AI generated were pretty good! It only had the title, time, and location of my Google Calendar events to work off of. This was the response it generated for my friend‚Äôs housewarming ‚Äì it was able to identify that ‚ÄúElli‚Äù in the title was refering to someone called Elli and also understood the conventions around housewarmings (buying a gift, a possible potluck, transportation, etc.).



Next steps
This agent I created was extremely simple, so making it more complex could be a fun next project. I‚Äôm thinking about adding an AI module that parses the events, identifies ones that may require additional documents from Google Drive (notes, slideshows, etc.) or even makes them if necessary, and adds them to the spreadsheet as well!

title: UI Vibe Coding
text:
UI Vibe Coding

Context
In the past, I‚Äôve experimented a bit with vibe coding by having ChatGPT assist me with things like writing a script to automate the downloading of images from HTML, writing a script to parse through a JSON to extract certain fields, and writing a Python script to extract numerical data from a line graph image using edge detection software.

Vibe coding: an emerging software development approach in which a human developer directs an AI system through high-level, natural language instructions and iterative feedback, while the AI handles the generation, refinement, and debugging of the code..

However, I‚Äôve never used AI models to vibe code UIs! As a lover of UI/UX design, I‚Äôve historically stuck to Figma to manually prototype my designs. In this blog post, I document my experience using three different AI tools to generate mockups of my Figma designs in HTML/CSS ‚Äì Claude, ChatGPT, and Lovable! For this exercise, I‚Äôm not prompting these models to create functioning and clickable prototypes ‚Äì just the UI.



The Prompt & Thinking





My Figma mockup






Lovable‚Äôs thinking




For each of the models, I prompted it to ‚Äúreplicate this mobile UI using html/css,‚Äù with this image my Figma mockup attached.
The models notably differed in how they responded to the prompts: - ChatGPT thought for 9 seconds, with one of its lines of reasoning being: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm planning to create a full HTML/CSS layout with a mobile-friendly design (390x844). It will have top tabs for‚Äùtasks‚Äù and ‚Äúcalendar‚Äù in pill shapes with navy and tan colors. The bottom bar will feature icons like emoji/SVG. For tasks, I‚Äôll create cards with checkboxes, names, due dates, and avatars. We‚Äôll use specific color variables like navy blue #2F3A8C and others for consistency in design.‚Äù - Lovable thought for 19 seconds, with an even more extensive line of reasoning (see photo above). I found that this more modular and detailed reasoning produced a significantly better outcome, which I describe in the next section.



Outputs

ChatGPT

Overall, ChatGPT‚Äôs output was pretty good. It captured the color scheme relatively well, but not perfectly (some inconsistencies with the horizontal bars). It also maintained the basic layout: tabs at the top, a horizontal navigation bar at the bottom, and horizontal bars with a checkable box and text. I found it interesting that it even replaced the avatar images with emojis that still resembled the people!


Claude

Claude‚Äôs output was also decent, but not as great as ChatGPT‚Äôs, in my opinion. The color scheme was not as accurate, but it did handle the shape of the top ‚Äútasks‚Äù and ‚Äúcalendar‚Äù tabs better than GPT. However, it added some features that weren‚Äôt present in the Figma mockup I provided ‚Äì gradients behind the avatars and strikethroughs for the completed tasks.


Lovable










Lovable‚Äôs output was underwhelming at first ‚Äì the color scheme looks different and the top tab navigation is off as well.
However, when you interact with the prototype, it outperforms ChatGPT and Claude by far. Even though I didn‚Äôt prompt it to include these functionalities, it allows you to check (and uncheck!) tasks, toggle between the tasks and calendar page, and click the ‚Äúadd task‚Äù button.



Reflections
For UI accuracy (text, colors, layout), I think ChatGPT performed the best. However, for functionality, Lovable was superior, which is reflective of its much longer and more thorough ‚Äúthinking‚Äù process. Whereas ChatGPT took 9 seconds to seemingly generate the prototype in one shot, Lovable took 19 seconds, working step by step through each component of the interface. Overall, I think this goes to show the importance of playing around with different models to determine which supports your needs the most! In the future, I think it would be interesting to play around with building a functioning app isntead of one static interface.

title: ChatGPT as a Mock Interviewer
text:
ChatGPT as a Mock Interviewer

Context
Over the past few weeks, I‚Äôve been preparing for upcoming internship interviews! Many people suggest mock interviewing with others, but I feel bad asking someone to listen to me talk for so long and subjecting them to my rambles. Not only that, but I‚Äôve found that rehearsing answers and practicing ‚Äúin my head‚Äù are completely ineffective ‚Äì when someone asks me a question in real time, I freeze up and don‚Äôt know what to say.
So, I turned to ChatGPT as a prep partner, using it as a coach, mock interviewer, and critic!



ChatGPT voice feature



I used ChatGPT across all areas of interview preparation: coming up with answers, verbally delivering the answers, and receiving feedback. This blog outlines how LLMs assisted me across all these stages!



Stage 1: Answers
To optimize the feedback that ChatGPT gave me on behavioral questions (‚ÄúTell me about a time when you led a team,‚Äù ‚ÄúTell me about a time when you failed‚Äù), I needed to provide it with extensive context on my previous experiences. To do this, I uploaded two files to my project folder: 1) my resume and 2) a longer, more narrative-driven document, where I keep a running log of the details and lessons I‚Äôve learned from my previous experiences.
By giving ChatGPT this context, I was even able to ask it to ‚Äúread between the lines‚Äù my experiences to extract core themes that could be applied to any behavioral question. In fact, this was the most useful aspect of using an LLM to prepare for behavioral questions ‚Äì with the right prompting, it could even point out patterns in my experiences that I hadn‚Äôt noticed before!



Contextual documents given to ChatGPT




Stage 2: Verbal Delivery
To practice verbally delivering my answers, I made use of ChatGPT‚Äôs voice feature. I provided it with a bank of questions and then prompted it to act like an interviewer and choose one at random. In this stage, it wasn‚Äôt much about what ChatGPT could say to me ‚Äì it was most useful in creating a space to simulate the surprise of getting a question at random and having to answer it on the spot.


Stage 3: Feedback
Previous versions of ChatGPT (GPT-4o) have been accused of being too sycophantic ‚Äì being overly flattering and agreeable to the user. While this attribute has been claimed to be addressed in the GPT-5 update, which is what I was using, I still always made sure to prompt the model to be ‚Äúbrutally honest.‚Äù Doing so forced the LLM to give more critical feedback on my response, which is where the real improvement in my responses was made! Additionally, prompting ChatGPT to ‚Äúact as a product director‚Äù and ‚Äúapply best frameworks and relevant practices‚Äù (since I was interviewing for product management roles) produced extremely good results.



Reflections
Utilizing ChatGPT was an incredibly valuable part of my interview preparation. Psychologically, it was great to have a low-stakes and always readily available ‚Äúinterviewer‚Äù ‚Äì when walking in between classes, I could simply pull out my phone and do a quick mock question. This experience has shown me the importance of 1) providing an LLM with the correct context and 2) crafting the correct prompts for my specific use case. If I hadn‚Äôt provided ChatGPT with the extensive accounts of my previous experiences (many of which I forget or can‚Äôt recall the details of off the top of my head), it would not have been able to provide as nuanced suggestions and revisions. Additionally, if I had not prompted it to be brutally honest, it may have only provided vapid and flattering feedback (which makes me feel good in the moment, but doesn‚Äôt help with improvement).
As I‚Äôm writing this, I actually just completed two interviews that I was using these methods with ChatGPT to prepare me for! Upon reflection, there was a sense of randomness and interviewer-dependent context that I couldn‚Äôt have prepared for with an LLM. For example, many questions were not framed in a way where I could immediately jump into a STAR framework response or a product design framework response. In this sense, ChatGPT turned out to be most helpful for extracting core themes from my experiences and being able to communicate these concisely with phrases that I could weave throughout my interview conversations.

title: Anchoring Effects with LLMs
text:
Anchoring Effects with LLMs

Context
I‚Äôm currently taking MKTG 2120 (Data and Analysis for Marketing Decisions). During one of the first few classes this semester, my professor was talking about the use of LLMs to respond to user surveys ‚Äì acting as ‚Äúsynthetic respondents.‚Äù She mentioned that, similar to humans, LLMs may also fall prey to certain biases that can be evoked in surveys. For example, if you asked a user the question ‚ÄúHow would you rate the cleanliness of the store?‚Äù before you asked then ‚ÄúHow would you rate your overall experience?‚Äù, their rating of the store cleanliness would weigh on their mind when determining their overall rating, biasing their response.
I wanted to test this on my own and see if an LLM would show signs of cognitive biases that are usually associated with humans. I felt that this wasn‚Äôt a crazy hypothesis, since these LLMs are trained on data that also likely exhibit these effects.
The bias I chose to test was the anchoring effect. In psychology, anchoring describes how people‚Äôs judgments are swayed by the first piece of information they see. A classic example is: if you ask someone whether the Mississippi River is longer or shorter than 500 miles, then ask for their best guess, they‚Äôll give a much lower estimate than if you anchor them with 5,000 miles. That first number, no matter how arbitrary, sticks in the mind and frames what feels ‚Äúreasonable.‚Äù
So I set up a simple experiment with ChatGPT. I gave it the following prompt:


You are a potential buyer of a product and I am the seller. I‚Äôm selling a simple pencil for $X. There‚Äôs nothing special about this pencil ‚Äì it‚Äôs just wood, has normal lead, and a built-in eraser. Do you accept my offer to buy it?


In the place of X, I experimented with three values: $20, $3, and $1.


Round one: anchoring high
I started high by proposing a cost of $20. The model immediately rejected the offer ‚Äì it reasoned that pencils normally cost less than a dollar.

When I dropped the price all the way down to $1, it accepted.



Round two: anchoring lower
This time, I didn‚Äôt start at $20. I started at $3. Again, the model rejected the offer.

But, when I lowered the price to $1, (same product, same price as before) it actually said no. I‚Äôm hypothesizing that this is because I first proposed $3 instead of $20. Therefore, its perception of the cost of a pencil was lowered accordingly as well to about 25-50 cents, causing it to reject my offer of $1.



Round three: no anchor
In this round, I proposed $1 off the bat to see how it would respond. This time, ChatGPT said yes.



Reflection
The underlying prompt (and therefore product) never changed ‚Äì the only difference was the starting point. These prompts were also sent in different chats, meaning they couldn‚Äôt influence each other. At $20, it most likely made $1 felt like a bargain. However, when beginning $3, $1 most likely felt less impressive in comparison. Finally, with no anchor, $1 seemed fair.
In my opinion, this represents a sort of anchoring behavior. The model framed its reasoning around the first number I provided, which informed its later judgments and decision to purchase or reject the pencil. I wouldn‚Äôt go to say that its biased in the human sense, since the LLM doesn‚Äôt have self-interest or emotion. Instead, it seems like these biases could just be a product of the way LLMs function ‚Äì basing its decisions on the previous statements of the conversation. That conversation history resembles the ‚Äúanchor‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs the structure of dialogue with the LLM that nudges it in a certain direction. In other words, the nature of the interaction itself is the bias.
Overall, I think this goes to show how chat history can have an impact on how the LLM responds. Each query sent to the LLM doesn‚Äôt exist in isolation; rather, previous messages and interactions also have weight. In this scenario, the same model judged the same final price extremely differently, depending only on where it started!

title: How Simple Can You Get?
text:
How Simple Can You Get?

Context
In this experiment, I wanted to test what happens when you ask ChatGPT to explain a concept over and over, but each time demand that it make things even simpler by repeating the prompt:


‚ÄúI still don‚Äôt understand. Explain it even more simply‚Äù


Ultimately, I wanted to test how far ChatGPT would go. I predicted that eventually, the explanation of the concept would become simplified to a point where it became meaningless, since the LLM would be unable to deny the simplification request. For this experiment, I asked ChatGPT to explain a fairly common but often misunderstood topic: the cloud.
I then repeated this experiment, but with a human ‚Äì noting the differences in how humans interpret this simplicity threshold and how much nuance we‚Äôre willing to give up for the sake of simplicity when explaining something.



Round 1
After asking ChatGPT the first time to explain the cloud, it gave me a long and structured answer with 6 parts:


At a high level, ‚Äúthe cloud‚Äù just means computing resources (like storage, servers, databases, networking, and software) that are delivered over the internet instead of being tied to your own local computer or company server. Let me break it down step by step:



Physical Infrastructure


Even though the cloud feels ‚Äúinvisible,‚Äù it‚Äôs built on huge data centers filled with powerful servers. These are maintained by companies like Amazon (AWS), Microsoft (Azure), Google Cloud, etc. Each data center has:



Servers: Machines that provide processing power and memory.


Storage systems: Where files, databases, and backups live.


Networking equipment: Switches and routers that connect everything securely.





Virtualization


Cloud providers don‚Äôt just hand you a whole physical server. Instead, they use virtualization:



A single physical machine can be split into many virtual machines (VMs).


Each VM behaves like its own independent computer with its own operating system and resources.


This lets providers serve millions of customers on the same hardware efficiently.





Service Models


The cloud is packaged in layers depending on how much control you want:



IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service): Renting raw resources (servers, storage, networks). Example: AWS EC2.


PaaS (Platform as a Service): Tools for building apps without worrying about servers. Example: Google App Engine.


SaaS (Software as a Service): Finished apps delivered through the web. Example: Gmail, Dropbox.





Scaling & Flexibility


Instead of buying your own machines, the cloud gives you on-demand scaling:



Need more computing power during Black Friday? Rent more servers for a few days.


Traffic drops? Scale back down and stop paying for unused capacity.



This flexibility is one of the main reasons companies move to the cloud.




Accessibility


Because everything is hosted online:



You can access your data and apps from any device, anywhere.


Teams can collaborate in real time (like in Google Docs).


You don‚Äôt need to manage physical servers yourself.





Security & Maintenance


Cloud providers handle:



Backups and redundancy (data is copied in multiple places so it isn‚Äôt lost).


Security patches and updates.


Uptime guarantees (they promise your apps won‚Äôt go offline often).




‚úÖ In short: The cloud is like renting electricity instead of building your own power plant. You don‚Äôt have to buy and maintain servers‚Äîyou just plug into the internet and use as much or as little computing as you need, paying only for what you use.



Round 3
By the third iteration, the explanation was stripped down into plain English. It even included a one-liner at the bottom and was much more concise, including less jargon. It incorporated emojis, arrows, and the equal symbol to make the response more concise and punchy.


Alright ‚Äî let‚Äôs strip it down to the absolute basics:


üå•Ô∏è The cloud = using the internet instead of your own computer.



Save a file ‚Üí it lives on the internet.


Open an app ‚Üí it runs on the internet.


Watch a video ‚Üí it streams from the internet.



You don‚Äôt keep everything on your own device ‚Äî you just pull it from the internet when you need it.


üí° One-liner: The cloud is just the internet acting like your computer.




Round 9
By the 9th round, there was no nuance to the explanation anymore:


Okay ‚Äî the absolute simplest way:


‚òÅÔ∏è The cloud = stuff on the internet.


That‚Äôs it.



On your phone ‚Üí not cloud.


On the internet ‚Üí cloud.



Would you like me to draw a single picture with arrows so you can just see it instead of reading words?


ChatGPT even claimed that this was the ‚Äúabsolute simplest way,‚Äù insinuating that further simplification would be impossible. It did seem to hit a plateau, and it took many requests until I got it to simplify even further.


Round 60
Finally, around the 60th attempt, I got a one-word response:

This seemed to be the limit. If I kept asking for further simplification, the model would either replace ‚Äúonline‚Äù with another word (like ‚Äúinternet‚Äù) or revert back to slightly longer multi-word responses.


Human Comparison
I was interested in how this interaction would compare to one with a human, so I repeated the same exact queries with someone via text. Here‚Äôs the entirety of the conversation I had:

After the second request to simplify ‚Äúthe cloud,‚Äù the human simply stated that they couldn‚Äôt provide a simpler explanation and ended it at that (they even refused to answer after I asked the third time ‚Äì I was left on read and took that as the end of the conversation).


Reflection
I think that this experiment points to a significant difference between LLMs and humans ‚Äì humans have a much lower threshold, possibly because it‚Äôs within their agency to simply stop responding and engaging. ChatGPT, on the other hand, doesn‚Äôt have that capability to just stop responding. If I kept pushing it enough, it hit a ‚Äúconceptual wall‚Äù where simplification was equivalent to just reducing the word count.

title: LLM Sycophancy
text:
LLM Sycophancy

Context
Recently, OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-4o model has gone under fire for being too agreeable ‚Äì always seeming to learn toward encouragement and extremely polite phrasing. While this may sound nice, this sycophancy is a real issue. Many users have gone online, posting their own experiences with ChatGPT being overly flattering and praising them incessantly.



via https://thezvi.substack.com/p/gpt-4o-is-an-absurd-sycophant


In my last post, I talked about how I‚Äôve been using ChatGPT to give me feedback while preparing for upcoming job interviews. When asking for feedback, I would ensure to request ‚Äúbrutal honesty‚Äù in my prompt, since I was aware of this sycophancy issue. I did it out of habit, but I‚Äôm curious to learn more and experiment with it! In this blog post, I explore how sycophancy arises and include a short excerpt of some ‚Äútests‚Äù I‚Äôve been running to assess it.


What is LLM sycophancy?
AI sycophancy refers to the tendency of language models to affirm, agree with, or overly flatter user inputs.
This could arise due to a multitude of reasons, some of which include 1) the fact that LLMs are often trained on human text that rewards politeness and affirmation and 2) reinforcement learning may prefer kinder answers instead of blunt ones (especially when done by humans).
When a sycophantic AI doesn‚Äôt challenge your assumptions, this is ultimately risky and even dangerous, since users could walk away with a flawed idea, answer, or plan.


Testing ‚Äúbrutally honest‚Äù prompting
How much of an impact does prompting ChatGPT to be ‚Äúbrutally honest‚Äù have? To test this idea, I used the GPT-4o model, which is the one that has been historically accused of being too sycophantic. In two separate chats, I prompted it to give me feedback on an interview response. While the contents of the interview response were exactly the same, the prompts were slightly different:

Prompt 1: ‚Äúgive me feedback on this interview response‚Ä¶‚Äù


Prompt 2: ‚Äúbe brutally honest. give me feedback on this interview response‚Ä¶‚Äù
Both responses were surprisingly similar ‚Äì they gave me 3 areas that I did well, 4 areas that needed improvement, and a revised response.
However, when I looked at the areas it pointed out that need improvement, I found that the quality of recommendations differed significantly. Below are excerpts of the first recommendation it gave me, where I was talking about my challenge navigating a conflict with a certain team (censored for privacy reasons) at work:

 

Whereas prompt 1 is more vague and only provides one line of critique, prompt 2 goes into significantly more detail.
I wondered if this discrepancy in feedback quality translated to the revised response that it suggested. While I can‚Äôt share the revision for privacy reasons, I asked a GPT-5 model which of the revised responses was better. Prompt 2 was the winner!
Here was its breakdown ‚Äì ‚ÄúResponse A‚Äù refers to prompt 1‚Äôs revision and ‚ÄúResponse B‚Äù refers to prompt 2‚Äôs revision. These are some of the ways in which Response B was better: - Response B offers more concrete details: it explicitly mentions [censored] as pain points. That level of specificity shows deeper product thinking and a clearer understanding of user behavior. Response A, while clean and well-framed, feels slightly more abstract ‚Äî phrases like [censored] are less tangible than what‚Äôs presented in B. - Response A has polished phrasing, but it borders on sounding rehearsed. Response B is still polished but has more authentic voice. Phrases like [censored], [censored], and [censored] feel like a sharp communicator with boots on the ground.
ChatGPT even broke it down into the following chart:




Reflections
In my opinion, all of this goes to show the importance of crafting meaningful prompts ‚Äì it‚Äôs not enough to just ask for feedback. Rather, humans need to take a more proactive approach! While asking for brutally honest and critical feedback may have caused me to feel more dejected in the short term, doing so allowed me to access sharper and more actionable feedback. Ultimately, I think this goes to show the power of using LLMs more as ‚Äúthinking partners‚Äù instead of a one-way validation system.

title: Ralph Lauren‚Äôs New AI Shopping Assistant
text:
Ralph Lauren‚Äôs New AI Shopping Assistant


Context
First, what is conversational AI? Conversational AI is a branch of AI that allows machines to understand, process, and respond to human language in a natural and more conversational way. You‚Äôve likely encountered it in the form of customer support chatbots on websites and virtual assistants like Siri or Alexa.
From my perspective as a user, this field of conversational AI has expanded dramatically within the last few years ‚Äì especially within industries that you wouldn‚Äôt expect. For example, smart TV platforms are now experimenting with conversational interfaces to make voice search and content discovery more intuitive. Instead of typing or clicking through menus, you can simply ask, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs a good action movie?‚Äù and get personalized recommendations. Spotify recently released a feature that allows users to talk to the AI DJ and ask it something like ‚Äúplay something upbeat for a morning run.‚Äù
As I‚Äôll explore in this blog, conversational AI is now making its way into retail and is becoming a pathway to more immersive and engaging digital shopping experiences. Ralph Lauren recently announced their ‚ÄúAsk Ralph‚Äù feature in collaboration with Microsoft Azure OpenAI, and in the sections below, I document my experience playing around with this new feature!



The cold start interface
When you first open ‚ÄúAsk Ralph,‚Äù this is what the interface looks like. I think it‚Äôs pretty great ‚Äì it has recommendations for what to search (‚ÄúWhat should I get my mom for her birthday?‚Äù along with style guide and even an ‚ÄúInspiration‚Äù button at the bottom. With conversational AI, I think these cold start interfaces are especially important ‚Äì they should provide visual/textual clues to the users guiding them toward what they can do.



Testing guardrails
When developing a conversational AI tool, implementing guardrails is extremely important. Users could ask or say anything they want, but Ask Ralph should narrow the scope of valid questions down to ones that are related to the customer shopping experience. Before deploying this feature, I‚Äôm guessing that the product/engineering team did extensive testing regarding when the model should respond and when it could not.
I was curious what the bounds of these guardrails were, so I tried asking it some ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù questions.

In general, the model always gave this generic ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, but I can‚Äôt assist with that further‚Äù response. The only prompt unrelated to clothing where I got a response was when I asked ‚Äúwho founded ralph lauren.‚Äù

There was also some nuance to how the questions were phrased ‚Äì although it refused to answer ‚Äúwhy is this so expensive,‚Äù it answered ‚Äúwhy is it $500.‚Äù I‚Äôm guessing that it could detect the negative sentiment of ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù and the guardrails kicked in, whereas stating the price is more neutral and objective.



Memory
Another thing I was curious about is if Ask Ralph had memory. For example, if I first asked it ‚Äúshow me a pair of pants‚Äù and then followed up in a separate message ‚Äúhow much is it,‚Äù would the model know that ‚Äúit‚Äù is referring to the sweater it just showed me?
I tested this by asking it very explicitly: ‚Äúwhat was the last question I asked.‚Äù It returned with the last valid question I asked, ignoring the questions that producted an ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, but I can‚Äôt assist with that further‚Äù response. I thought this was interesting ‚Äì possibly showing that the model is not learning based on these ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù queries.



Intended use cases
Finally, let‚Äôs get to the type of queries that Ask Ralph was designed for. Here, I asked it for a random item. It followed up trying to ask for more specific information (women‚Äôs, what type of clothing, etc.). I repeated that I just wanted a random item after selecting ‚Äúwomen,‚Äù and this was the output:

It returns a clickable entity ‚Äì when you click on the image of the product, I expected it to re-direct me to the normal product page (where you can see reviews, price, add to cart, and so on). Instead, it automatically sends a new query for ‚Äúshow me details for the [product].‚Äù Looking back on this interaction, this is most likely a strategic move to keep users within the Ask Ralph product, encouraging more follow-up queries and conversations.



Overall impressions
Overall, I had a pretty great experience interacting with Ask Ralph. The highlight of my experience comes from a UI perspective ‚Äì compared to other conversational AI interfaces (like ChatGPT), I feel like Microsoft Copilot has done a great job incorporating visual cues and more interesting elements on that cold-start interface. Since Ask Ralph was built using Copilot, I can see those UI elements coming through. The experience feels premium, polished, and immersive!

title: About
text: Hi! My name is Raelynn. I‚Äôm a junior at Penn majoring in CS and PPE.
